Replies.Reply: Dramatically lit by sunlight filtering down from the surface.
The wreck of the working fisherman's boat "ORCA," formerly under the command of the late Captain Quint, deceased these four years.
Distant flashes, obscured by vegetation in the foreground.
Thank you, Paul Lohman, for that eloquent solo. Now, for that point in the ceremonies where we formally dedicate this magnificent resort-

Len Peterson's Amity Shores Development is an exciting addition to our island. The Holiday Inn we stand in is likewise a new friend who we welcome as family. Amity means 'friendship' and our community extends its friendship to all who seek her shores in peace and harmony.

Tina was selected from more than 20 of this island's lovely young ladies in the Miss Amity competition held every spring, and she'll represent Amity Island in the Miss Massachusetts Competition in Worcester next month. When she cuts this ribbon, she will be opening our island to growth, to development, to planned expansion with full employment for our thriving community.
Thanks to Tom Andrews, of Amity Aqua-
Hello, hello. It went well, I thought.
Thank you, thank you. You know my son, don't you?
I'm showing summer rentals. We got a helluva season going.
No one has seen a shark -- no fin, no bites, nothing. Be realistic.
Of course I can, but can't it wait? These things cost money, and this town doesn't have much money.
We have done something -- hell, we damn near went broke putting up a shark watch tower on the beach -- it's the only one in 2000 miles, y'know.
their beaches! In New England? We all lost on that one.
Martin, when we build up our tax base a little, you can have everything you want; right now, the town's broke.
A tragedy. But that was a boating accident; no bites, no sharks, nothing but a boating accident.
There's always deaths in these waters that never turn up. Are they all shark victims?
What am I, an ass? When you called me, I called Elkins, and her bosses. Nothing she saw is proof of anything.
Don't push it this time. If you do, it won't turn out the way you want, I guarantee you that.
I've got to get back to work.
You know where your dad is?
Len, can I see you a minute?
Maybe nobody will notice. Let's get them back in the bus.
It's an observation platform. That's our Chief of Police. He's just checking it.
He thought he had a good reason.
Look, what am I supposed to do? It's done, it's over. We have to deal with the consequences.
All right. Let's go into my office, where we can have a little privacy.
Chief -- the Board of Selectmen has a question only you can answer.
Martin, could you wait here for a few minutes while we make up our minds about something?

Very well then. It is moved and seconded that Martin Brody be relieved of his duties as Chief of Police, his contract with the township be terminated, and that Jeff Hendricks be appointed Acting Chief in the interim. Those in favor?
I'm sorry, but I respect his convictions. The motion is carried.
Martin? Could you come in please?
I can see that. Don't you know this is a big deal?
Terrific. Act as if you've been here all along.
My boss and your boss. Sure.
And how. I thought you wouldn't respect me.
Put a towel down. And shh -- daddy's sleeping.
You have to smoke so early in the morning?
He doesn't have to work all the time, it's his vacation.
Why don't you take a half day and clean this junk up?
Sort of -- Matthew Hooper is aboard the research vessel Aurora, presently in the Antarctic Ocean, and won't be in radio range until half-past next spring.
Oh, perfect -- a 75 per cent family affair. Where were you?
Use the little brush there. Why were you at Santos'?
Oh. Want to talk about it?
Are you going to be able to sleep?
A piece here, a piece there, it all adds up.
Moving after her husband, while Mike steadies Sean, holding the impulsive kid back.
Stop that! We're not going any place. You love it here. Tell me what the hell happened!
Shhhh. Go back upstairs. Daddy's sleeping.
What're you going to do today?
Sean's not up yet. You know what he likes, just some Fruit Loops and milk. No candy.
Hey -- it's not your job any more. I'm going to be late for work.
What is it? What's the matter?
My purse is on that boat.
How'm I supposed to do that?
Do I have to talk to those two?
All of us thank you, okay?
Can you take a little time out from your busy schedule to dance with the old man?
Listen -- what are you doing later?
You're getting a little big for this.

Replies.Didascalie: (walking onto the dock, Sean tagging along)

Replies.Reply: Then check it out. I'll be in the office.
Thanks. What else is out there?
I'll take the exhibitionist, you handle the others.
Talk to me about Mrs. Kinney.
Hendricks. I want to go over your reports and your Form 908.
I just made it up. It means, "Get me out of there."
Abandoned? It's a little early in the season for that.
hell wouldn't leave it anchored alone in the channel.
Hendricks, get a description of that dance.
There should be bodies. Witnesses say two people; one in the boat, one skiing.
Stay on it. I don't care how long it takes.
You could work out at the beach, make a few bucks for school.
You'll have to make up your own mind about that.
Because, I'm in the middle of a boating accident, I got only four regular cops and one secretary, and a Chief Deputy who is constantly fiddling with the police boat. He's another one.
Boat nut. What is it about this place that makes everyone a freak for boating?
What about tennis? Riding? Fixing up old cars? Bartending?
Okay, not bartending. Why on the water every day?
Look, humor the old man -- just be careful.
Don't go out if it's rough or anything, huh? We've had a lot of trouble.
You stay with Mrs. Silvera, Tootsie. Okay?
As soon as I heard about it, I called you. This thing is big!
Come on, let's check the bite radius.
Bite radius. You know, the size of the mouth?
The shark that did this. It was a shark, wasn't it?
But that's what we're here to find out, right?
Look, I know a little bit about sharks.
Is there one in these waters?
Jesus, don't quibble with me. I want to know if a Great White Shark did this.
Could you just keep that crowd back, please?
You stay right here. You're going in with me.
I don't want to discuss it.
No more sailing. You come back with me, and that's it.
We have got to talk, and we have got to talk alone.
Larry, I don't know how to say this, but I think we got a shark problem. A real one.
I got a feeling. I have to act on it -- you can understand that, can't you?
Two of them are still missing!
Bullshit? I'll give you bullshit -- there's a dead whale out there with bites all over it!
Come on, give a guy a break.
You didn't miss much. Christ, what a mess.
The woman passenger on the boat that blew up.
That one -- from the wreck. You brought it up, did you look inside it?
The drugstore's closed? What the hell time is it?
Oh yeah -- I'm expecting a long distance call, very important. Give them my home phone.
That's what I said. Is there any of that hand cleaner stuff?
Found one of the missing victims from that boat deal.
You want to come here a minute?
I got something for you to do tomorrow.
Forget it. You're beached. Grounded. No more boats.
No backtalk! I spoke to Upton, at the beach, and he's got a job for you there. You can work until school starts.
He wanted a job, he's got one. I want to see that boat out of the water by tomorrow night.
Tomorrow night. Out of the water.
I know what you're going to say.

In the city, it happened all the time -- some Kid o.d.'s on a rooftop, top, a drunk gets cut in pieces under the Brooklyn local, old people die alone in shitty apartments and three weeks later someone calls the cops because of the smell and the flies. Call the cops. What are we, immune?
The goddamn smell is always the same.
Mike! Keep it down, for chrissake!
Out of the water! Everyone out of the water!
Get out of the water! Tell everyone to get out! Now! Out of the water!
Out of the water! Now! Everyone!
No! Don't go in! Stay out! Stay clear!
You said something about a camera.
Come on, Phil, don't jerk me around.
Thank God you guys were all together. I got something for you. Proof!
Look -- I just got this from Phil Fogarty. It was in the camera belonging to the missing divers. It proves I was right, all along.
It's a shark! A Great White! Jesus, it's right there!
What are you all, blind? It's a shark. Look -- teeth, jaw, gills.
You're damn right that's what it is.

What the hell does it take to make sense to you numbskulls? Jesus, it's right there in front of you. I know what a goddamn shark looks like, I've been through it, don't you understand? I've seen this sonofabitch before!
Is that what it is? Dollars? Money? I'll pay for it. Take it out of my salary.
Maybe I don't make as much money as some bullshit rip-off artists around here, but I don't work the same way.
It means I don't like all that grab-
Ooohh, nothing. I just got fired, that's all.
Then that's what I meant. Fired. Canned. Out on my fanny. The Selectmen just made Hendricks the new Chief of Police. Just like that.
Turn in the car. Clean my desk, explain things to our sons, then maybe get shit-faced and punch your boss.
Don't rush into it -- we may need the income.
Mike left early. Couldn't wait to make out. Must be a morning man.
Frankie. Okay. Ask him if he needs an apprentice.
Goddamnit, Hendricks, untie the rope there.
Find the Kids. The lighthouse -- you said something about the lighthouse. Get us there.
Amity Launch to Harbor Patrol, over.
Affirmative. Can you get your chopper airborne?
Get him the hell over to Amity Point, the old lighthouse. Right now.
There's a bunch of Kids day-sailing that way. Turn them back to port.
That's it. Just do it, all right?
If they're not at the light, look for them. I don't want them out there. Get them back to port!
It's okay, it's okay. What's the matter? Tina? Honey? Hey --
I knew it. I goddamn well told them.
Skip that. What about those kids out sailing?
Get her in. Get them both in.
Never mind that shit. Just point.
Amity Launch to Patrol Air Unit One. Harbor Air, where are you?
It's me. Any fix on those Kids?
For Christ's sake, get going! I'm all alone out here!
Where the hell is Francis Shoal?
Harbor Air, this is Brody. Air One, come in.
Harbor Air, do you read? Over?
Where the hell is Air One?
At least you're safe. What about the others?
Jesus, don't freeze on me. What about the others?
Stay here. Don't go anywhere. Just stay here.
Can you get a line to me?
Son of a bitch is stuck!
climbs back onto the boat, starts the winch engine, trying to pull the cable free.
Come on, you bastard, come on, pull. Pull!
Andy! Use the lights! The lights!
Possessed, yelling at the top of his lungs.
Come and get me! Come and get me!

watching, cowering on the rubber raft to which he fell when the shark hit the cable. It's strangely silent. The lights on Cable Junction flicker and die as circuit breakers shut down the mains, protecting the line. Only the boat's worklights provide light now.
I don't think she's such hot stuff.
Anyone got a spare mooring line? Mine's shot.
Mike and Larry are racing! Loser goes home alone!
Your ass I will. Besides, the wind's turning with the tide. Sailing back is going to be a bitch.
At least. And an offshore wind.
If we can get to it.
But we had it! We were headed right for it!
When are we going out? You and me?
Listen, Jane -- you want to dance as soon as we get out of these monkey suits?
Anyone want to sail to the lighthouse?
Anyone want to go the lighthouse?
Nah. Tomorrow. Early, spend the day. My folks left two cases of beer in the garage.
Nope. Got it in my boat.
A shark hit us out there.
The others are ratted together. Drifting.
Mom, Michael won't talk to me.
Michael, Michael, Dad said to find you.
I want to go out with you. You need a crew, don't you?
Do I have to play with the little kids?
You eat Cheerios. I want Fruit Loops.
Can I go with you today?
Bye, Daddy. I'm going to be careful, all day.
I want to go with you!
I'm not in the way. Andy, am I in the way?
Is that big thing still out there?
Are we going to go on the island?
They made me go with them.
The speech was right on the money.
Be a love and make sure the bar's open, will you?
Fantastic lady. Don't know what I'd do without her.
Y'know, Brody -- for the first time in years it's worth putting money into this town.
Heck of a way to treat a taxpayer.
Don't you have any pull with the chief, here?
Better get a sales kit together for after lunch. I'm taking some prospects out.
Can't we fix it up to get this made into a green zone or something?
This is the town beach; the development naturally has its own private access, but I wanted you to see the concession area. Look at that sand -- like sugar!
And if you have any questions about recreational possibilities, Ellen Brody here will be happy to answer them.
I think we got a couple of live ones.
How the hell do we get him down from there?
Normally, it's used for, ah, bird watching. Nature observation. Weather measurements, that sort of thing.
What the hell is he doing?
You should've been out there. You should've seen him waving that gun, like a maniac. There were shots fired!
Larry, I'm a businessman, trying to make a buck like anybody else.
So it can't be done like that. The man's a menace, plain and simple.
Is Jeff Hendricks qualified to fill in as an interim Chief of Police in your absence?
It came up during the meeting.
What have you seen before? This is nothing. Seaweed. Mud. Something in the lens.
Will you listen to this man? Will you just listen to him?
You really caused a panic on a public beach, you shoot up the place, God knows who could've been injured -- what if somebody decides to sue us? That could ruin us.
I won't mention his personal attack on me.
And Hendricks is qualified, you heard that from his own mouth.
Anyone opposed, or is it unanimous?
I'm not crazy about blind dates.
No place special. Just hanging out.
I said, 'No.'  Tina's in her boat, "Tina's Joy," a neat sloop. Mike is going over his "Green Machine," a sleek catamaran.
I don't need you. Andy's here.
I don't know about him -- I'm going down to the dock, maybe go sailing.
What else is there to do?
I'll be careful. I'll see y'later.
We got some stuff at the store. Ed and Tina are going to be there.
Too hot for those two? I can't believe it.
I'll be right there. Wait up.
We came out in my boat.
That's not it. My dad told me not to go.
Look -- if you're going to get in the way, you can just go home.
I can go out if I want to.
We're fighting wind and current. I though we'd be out longer, catch the incoming tide.
I passed out, but I'm okay.
My cousin will be here tomorrow.
You're not going out right away, are you?
I want you to meet my cousin.
Over here. I want you to meet somebody.
The lighthouse is a make-out spot.
You going to fool around with Mike?
Well, I'm not doing anything with him.
Anyone want a coke or anything?
She just likes to tease. I think she really likes you.
That's okay -- I'll go with Timmy.
Tide doesn't turn for three hours.
So all we have to do is land at Cable Junction and wait.
They're okay, if they got little white canes and tin cups.
Did your mom put all this together?
Is she responsible for the punch?
Mostly old garbage. Today we found a '48 Hudson.
Who's that? Quick -- I'm in love.
Oh, out a ways. Maybe the lighthouse.
No big thing, we'll see who's out there, maybe picnic.
I'll tie up at the town dock, don't worry, man.
Hey, it's all bullshit. Anyone want to play pong for money?
If you're beached, why are we doing this? For practice?
Then why are we futzing around the dock? We can make a few bucks working at the beach.
Put him down in the water.
You've just made someone very happy.
I could give you a dozen good reasons.
Okay, okay, don't say I didn't remind you.
Today I'm staying topside. You dive for me!
Like hell! We're on the starboard tack!
We're going to be fighting the current.
Wind's backing around a few points, too.
You're betting what you already got.
Sure you do -- you win either way.
Your dad must be really pissed.
It's not going to be easy.
Putz -- that won't be for hours.
If he liked your boat, I got some sneakers he'll love.
What'd you do? Memorize the tide tables?
Can you put us on Cable Junction?
How about a tow? Can you rig that?
Sean! Listen! Listen to me, Sean.
Goddamn it, Sean, you listen to me or I will kick your ass, do you hear me?
We're throwing a rope and you better catch it, hear?
Keep an eye out for that fish.
Bring her to port a little. That's it -- steady.
Hang on, hang on -- we got it. You're on!
Doesn't hurt to ask. Sometimes the most beautiful girls are the loneliest.
I wonder what the Brebner twins are doing tomorrow night.
That's what I want -- a gaff rig.
Did he really freak out at the beach?
I'm getting new sails, then watch out. Just a question of modifying the rigging!
Hey! Wait for the H.M.S. Invincible!
Make way for the Carrier Enterprise!
Mr. Christian! Mr. Christian! Pump up this boat! And shave that silly moustache!
You sail your boat, I'll sail mine.
I'm telling you, a goddamn shark ate my goddamn boat!
Low tide at Cable Junction is 7:46 p.m.
I can't help it, it sticks in my mind.
They tend to follow moving things. Maybe it's following Polo and Timmy.
By 7:46, when the tide turns around, we'll be twenty miles out. More, with this wind.
I think we're changing course a little.
You're crazy. She's Ed's girl friend.
Gaff rigged? Why not a staysail schooner? Go anywhere. Look at this -- the Mayan, an Alden schooner.
With the current. Towards Cable Junction.
Same tired old faces. You see Vaughn?
If you see him, tell him I got a six-
Hey, Mike -- I saw your dad over at the town hall.
I thought you said she was going with us?
Anyone got another set of sails?
Can you get us a line?
Tie it off on your left. Your other left!
Till noon. This is on my own time.
Want me to run out there?
Rich or poor, it's nice to have money.
Happens every season -- someone takes off. Once we had a schooner for a month while the owners went fox hunting.
Diver's camera. Tom Andrews brought it up from under that abandoned cruiser.
Rich people. Home port is Newport, Rhode Island.
I can't find anyone out here. They must've gone to the bottom, or drifted with the current.
For how long? Current's moving everything around, and it's getting dark.
Untangle it and let's go -- We don't need a blackout on the island.
I can't hear you if you're going to whisper.
We got a helluva tide this month.
I missed you at the funeral home. Santos said you were here.
I know just where to go.
Of course not, They're closed. Phil Fogarty's place. He'll do it for me.
Right after, the Kids went out?
All of them. Mike, Junior Vaughn, Brookie Peters, Pat, Lucy -- all that whole gang.
Yep. Looked like they were headed to the lighthouse.
Uh, Chief -- look. You're not Chief any more.
I can't let you take her out.
Mrs. Brody, look -- if he can't go, then you can't go. Neither of you can go.
But I signed for the boat. You're not authorized any more.
What the hell, they can't fire both of us -- someone's got to be in charge, right? Which way are we going?
See where Cable Junction is? Look to the left. The lighthouse. That's it.
You got a gold-plater drifting in the main channel. Big cruiser.
Off the Point. No running lights, just a diver's flag.
If we beat them, they can both go home stag! Single-O! Alone! Jackie can come back in this boat!
As long as we're drifting, might as well go with the flow.
First we got to get there.
He's got to help or it won't work.
Take a break for a minute, okay?
Can we go skiing? We can use my Uncle's boat. Eddie?
With you, everything's next week. I want to go skiing soon. Tomorrow?
We heard this noise, like a 'boomp' out there, and when we looked, there was just this cloud of smoke.
Chief Brody -- can we go? Please?
You want to tack, or just leave her pointed up like this?
It'll take us to Budapest if you're not careful.
What're we going to do in the mean time?
Wait a minute. Promise me something.
That you'll put down a blanket. I've got black and blue marks all over my butt, and my Mom's getting uptight about them.
her mouth working silently, unable to scream, staring down at the blood and froth on the water, swirling in a grim eddy under her, the Sandpiper rocking gently in the diminishing swell.
Up on the street, where a pretty girl with a sexy face and a provocative post-pubescent walk is asking him directions.
Now I really want to see it.
Is there something I don't know about?
Oh, yeah. So why aren't they doing it now?
We'll be over by the lighthouse.
This is fun! Can we go faster?
I'd like to go out to the lighthouse with you.
No way. Everybody's going sailing. If you don't want to take me, just say so.
You do everything your parents tell you?
Good. I'll be on the dock at eight.
I really want to to be there.
Who's bringing the wine? And who's got a quarter for the box?
Is there room on your boat for all of us?
When do we get to the lighthouse?
I can't wait to get there.
That's fun! Let's race for something!
You have to take us off! You have to! Why don't you take us!
It killed her. It ate her.
I don't want to die! Mommy!
Hey, get out of our air!
I thought you might still be painting the restrooms at the beach.
How about a side bet to make it interesting?
It's a bet. Once around the marker buoy?
So much for the rubber duck.
Tie off to your strongest point.
Anyone know what time it is?
What the hell, we're steering for it.
It's bad enough without her freaking out.
Silent, green-blue depths. A diver, Crosby, working the bottom, running a search pattern. Another diver, Tom Andrews, running close. They signal to each other, and make another pass.
I don't care about the overtime, I'm hungry. And cold. And most of all, bored.
It comes here from Cable Junction.
Now you're talking. Let's get out of here before we do find something.
Hey! Nicholas! You're supposed to be in class!
Sparky will take you down today. If everyone's got a buddy, we'll drop.
One petty theft, one domestic disturbance, and an exhibitionist.
Chief Brody? I want you to do something about my first husband.
Martin, you have got to demand that Grace Kinney keep her shades down.
Grace Kinney is driving my boy to distraction.
Looking up at the surface, where a hull floats in silhouette against the daylight. There's a commotion, and a water ski drops into view. Then another one. Pale legs churn the water.
following the skis effortlessly, closing in on the turbulent wake.
Closing in on the wake, crossing it.
Closing in on the thrashing figure.
The class, paired up, is drifting down; Sparky offering encouragement as they descend. Andrews and Crosby are already disappearing, swimming away with strong kicks.
The Sandpiper's hull, alone above us, as the Shark rises with dreadful certainty, attracted by the erratic sounds of Ed's hasty search.
The twin hulls of a catamaran's hull, the muffled, eerie sound of drumming, as the water carries the tempting "thud-
Looking up at the scattered hulls of the sailboats, the turbulence from the low-flying chopper making a vast circular pattern of irregular vibrations.
looking up at pontoons, wreckage, wind turbulence on the surface, the heavy "thud-thud-thud" of chopper blades.
Marge ducking under the bulk of the Shark, shoving off with panicky reserves of strength, swimming away underwater, while the Shark takes a massive crunching bite out of a submerged hull.
The inverted mast of one of the wrecked boats is snagged on the rocks on the bottom.
the mast bends under the strain, but holds the raft stuck fast.
Did you ever see a dolphin?
Screaming, as the Shark rises from the deep and takes her.
Sure. They like to play. We may see some today.
A last flash before the gasoline explodes.
The tide's running. It'll take us to the light.
They'll be there when we get there. Might even have a fire started.
I dunno. We'll think of something.
Terry whipping along; a fin raises near her. She glances at it, waves, thinking it's a porpoise.

The fin cuts across her path. Too late to maneuver, Terry hits the looming gray back of the Shark. The skis bump, leave the water, Terry takes a spectacular spill. The rope around her waist tows her helpless through the water, gagging her, preventing her from shouting. She flounders as Diane slows the boat to see what's happened.
Looking around for her friend, suddenly panicky. She pulls the rope hard, and tumbles backward as it comes up with nothing on it -- just a cleanly bitten end.
He's on the porch of tile Witherspoon house, using his portable walkie-talkie. Mrs. Witherspoon is waiting in the b.g.
That was the explosion. One minute they were having a wonderful time, the next, bang!
I don't know what could've done that.

Hendricks has the winch in operation, the cable in his hand, with big grappling hooks attached. The boat is lit by its powerful worklights. Hendricks heaves them out, watches as the current takes them, then puts the winch in gear, hauling back.
It goes taut with a sudden strain.
The huge hulk of a beached, decomposing dead whale, a few birds still pecking at scraps of blubber and entrails. Big festering red holes mark its sides.
From the tip of the snout, please.
We don't know that, do we?
You don't tell me my job, and I won't tell you about yours, okay?
Could be a shark. But maybe not.
What makes you think there might be?
This is a mammal, not a fish.
Sound. Like sonar, or radar. They home in on irregular sounds, unusual sounds, any rhythmic low-frequency vibration.
Not necessarily. These wounds could've been inflicted 30 miles out to sea, or more. None of them are immediately fatal. Currents could've carried the body 10 miles further.
Lower jaw displaced and lacerated by predator attempt to seize the tongue. Additional large tissue loss in the dorsal and sub-
It's either a Great White, or another killer whale.
Not when it's like this. This animal has been ashore for 10, 12 hours, and drifting for a day, at least. Every little nibbler in the sea's taken a bite.
Don't be ridiculous -- Sharks don't take things personally.

Macro close on a pharmaceutical bottle of Sodium Cyanide, from which a syringe is withdrawing a healthy dose. Follow the syringe and reveal Brody, working at his desk in the deserted office. He is injecting the deadly chemical into some jacketed .38 hollow-point ammunition; a dozen cartridges are lined up in neat array, he is filling the last of them, sealing the points with wax from a burning red candle. The radio scanner is monitoring the local police band: routine reports faintly in the b.g. -- a slow night in pre-season Amity.
Hello -- selling some more of the good life?
Your husband's been here all morning. What's he doing?
So Jeff could handle things? He knows the routine, he has the authority?
It's underwater, isn't it? That's why it's so dark.
I'm sorry, I just don't see it.
I've never seen him like this.
sweeping the water with binoculars, restless eyes trying to scan everything, a grim watchman high over the heads of the unseeing crowd.
still scanning. His body suddenly tenses. There's something out there. He mashes his binoculars to his eyes, trying to get a better look.

Larry Vaughn, Jr. comes skimming in close to the surf. Bob is handling the sheets, Larry is giving young Jackie sailing lessons -- at the moment he's showing her how the tiller works.  He's on her like glue.
Vaughn waves back, preoccupied. Near him, Mike Brody looks up, his face grim, jealous, and now a little nuts. He splashes paint onto the wood with angry abandon.
It's a shark tower. I saw one in Florida. He's looking for sharks.
Through the binoculars, something big and black, moving under the buoys and into the swimming area.
far above him, the class, going about their business.
He can't believe it. But looking past him, we can see it with the unaided eye: a seething dark mass, moving through the water towards the unprotected bathers.
The dark mass almost on top of the swimmers, who are starting to look around. Most of them are oblivious to what's happening on shore.

as his feet hit the sand and he starts running for the water, fumbling for his gun and the speed-loader with the cyanide bullets. He is bumping into people, knocking little kids over, stepping on blankets and umbrellas, a madman.
It's bluefish! It's a school of bluefish! Chief! It's bluefish!
We made a motion and it was already seconded.
That's what we're here to do.
I don't know -- what is it?
Let's see -- you got a minute?
Brody stares down at it. Sure enough, the ghostly outlines of the Orca, underwater, a diver on the deck making a gesture at the camera.
Quietly gaining contrast in a pan of developer, a print of what at first looks like seaweed, then is unmistakably the grinning jaws of the Great White.
Ed's hands on the rail, knuckles white, an iron grip. With awful finality, the force pulls down, and the wood shatters and splits away as Ed's hands are pulled down and under by the awful force.
A quick nightmare vision of Brody, alone in a sinking Orca, trapped in a battered cabin interior; a Great White crashes through the glass, its head huge as it lunges.

The close-up detail of this otherwise blurred and unreadable photo is unmistakably a detail from a very close view of the snapping jaws of a Great White; if you hadn't seen it as a memory, it would make no sense at all. For Brody, the meaning is all too clear; for anyone who's never seen the monster face-to-face, it's nothing.
Just as before, an ambiguous pattern of light and dark; not proof of anything without Brody's inner vision.
This guy giving you any trouble?
You want to go out in my boat?
As the Pilot overtakes her -- a moment of horror, as she thinks the Shark has found her, then relief, as the Pilot motions to the bubble, and indicates "Air." She follows him.

Lots of day-sailing Kids, a few bigger, adult boats, some working fishermen and sport fishers; a typical recreational boating mix. The Kids are finding the same general direction, pointing out of the harbor.

The Amity Police Boat, Brody, Ellen and Hendricks aboard, is headed under full power out to sea. Hendricks is pumping the horn, warning boats out of the way, ignoring the rules of the road; as small boats scatter out of the way, we can see the ambulance, red light flashing, pushing out slowly through the crowd at dockside.
The dive class boat, isolated near the channel, a group of Kids in wet suits and tanks assembled with three adult instructors: Tom Andrews, Crosby, and Sparky.

The Great White Shark, taking the striper in a single gulp, it's looking up at Andrews with one glassy doll's eye; it turns to face him directly, and we see the scar; ugly, red and black, charred flesh from jaw back on the right side, eyes and teeth gleaming like raw bone in the massive, uncaring face.
look over at the rocketing ascent. What's wrong? Sparky signals "up," and they begin to carefully follow him towards the surface. Crosby's already surfacing.
Get us in! For Christ's sake, get us in!
Embolism. Air bubbles in his blood. Came up too damn fast. Held his goddamn breath!
Tina is staring down at the water, terror-stricken; Ed's arms and head are f.g., as he locks onto the boat with desperate hands.
The dive boat is moored at a clumsy angle next to the Police Boat, where Hendricks has been pulling routine maintenance.
Andrews is shaking, bloody froth on his lips and chest. The shaken divers are huddled together, an ambulance attendant is wheeling a gurney into position. Crosby and Sparky are stunned.
It's okay. We're taking care of him.
Brody is casting off lines. Ellen is on the dock, watching him.
Harbor Patrol. Is that you, Brody?
10-4, in a few minutes. He's down checking a buoy in the Bay Channel.
10-4, soon as I can raise him.
Affirmative, affirmative. Turn the Kids day-sailing back to port. I heard you. Patrol out.
That's what I'd like to know. Lost transmission at Cable Junction.
Then nothing. If you see him, tell him to switch to an operational frequency, or give me a status report yourself.
1530 hours. Might still be there. Base out.
Pat and Lucy are trimming sail, moving faster.
--  Ropes and sails rattling through blocks.
It's the chopper's point of view, as the Harbor Patrol copter from the Cape flies towards the Kids, following Brody's previous instructions. He sees the sailboats and fly that way.
This is the Harbor Patrol. Return to port immediately. Return -- to -- port -- immediately.
Patrol One to Base. Looks like they're turning back.
I got no room for passengers.
Listen. I'm going to give you an assist to get you on Cable Junction. Then I'll call in, and get the Coast Guard to send a cutter. Hang on to something.

Characters.Character: LOOKING UP AT THE APPROACHING COPTER

Replies.Reply: It approaches the sailboats, losing altitude fast, rotor blades chuffing up a storm.
The Kids look at each other, some coming about awkwardly, others luffing, wondering what this is all about.
All right, Patrol. Go back to work. You've wasted enough time.
It wheels around, and heads back towards land.
This is Cape Patrol -- what is it, Brody? I heard you weren't chief anymore.
It's all okay -- Colby got to them. They were turning back when he left 'em.
Sure. He's got work to do in Bay Channel.
The Shark has fixated on something -- one outlying shape, the easily identifiable outline of Doug's inflatable, thumping and putting. It homes in on the sound.
Patrick and Lucy ram into Timmy's boat, locking into it, knocking Timmy into the water as Brooke screams.
As the following events take place:  --  Larry's red cat rams and locks onto Mike's Tornado.

Brody, looking up from his chart, scans the ocean. Ahead is the Lighthouse, his immediate destination. Out of sight to the right, Cable Junction, and beyond that, 2500 miles of cold Atlantic. Brody looks up from his chart, and grabs the radio.
This is Air One. That you, Brody?
The Amity Police Boat, under full power, surging through the heavy swell, Brody very much alone at the helm.

floating in the current, drifting away from the lighthouse, towards the open sea. Floating on the wreckage and tangled boats are:  Doug, Andy, Jackie, Patrick, Lucy, Larry, Bob, Brooke, Marge, and Sean.
More sail, some improvised rigging, Patrick and Lucy trimming what there is, trying to steer the clumsy contraption. From afar, the distant sound of an approaching chopper.
The helicopter is creating a lot of turbulence as it sets down, a huge circular pattern of prop-wash on the surface as the rotors slow to a halt. The Kids are waving and jubilant.
With the kids reaching out hands, sticks, rope, anything to pull the little one to safety. The ocean swells rise and fall with hidden menace.

bursts apart from the center as the Shark lunges up through the canvas trampoline of the Sizzler. The Kids, screaming, fall into the water as the attack forces the fragile structure into pieces. Only Sean, Brooke, and Jackie are left on the remaining segment.

Characters.Character: WIDE ON THE RAFT AND CHOPPER

Replies.Reply: In the f.g., the fin rises, and starts for the scene.
attacks one of the pontoons, biting down on it, clamping great scarred jaws onto the bulbous floats.
rising like grey doom, then dropping out of sight. Marge is gone.
surfaces, and moves purposefully towards the gap that separates the police boat from the raft. It lunges at Brody as it passes the launch; the fin hits the taut rescue line, snapping it.
on the offensive now, takes an outrigger pontoon, biting it, tearing it off the raft, shaking everything.
turns, bleeding from a superficial cut on its snout, its scar glistening wet and terrible. It heads for Brody.

Attacking. Missing Brody, who hauls himself up out of the way in life-or-death spasm. The great jaws close, fastening onto the thick cable. Shaking it. The cable resists for a moment, then splits, layers or insulation and armor crack open, the jaws clamp harder -- 20,000 tons of pressure -- then the live copper core is reached. Zap!
dying. Leaping and convulsing as hundreds of thousands of volts surge through its body, grounded in the salt sea. Hot white fire shimmers like a halo, the fish smokes and stinks, sputters, and dies.
The Kids watch, horror-stricken, as the giant Shark hangs on the roaring copter; in the b.g., Cable Junction is looming closer. The copter tilts dangerously, the Shark bites deeper, harder.
reacting, ducking in terror. Huge chunks of disintegrating rotors are flying all around. Masts and sails left standing before are chopped into a deadly salad. Screams.
go crazy, waving, yelling, screaming, "Over here!" "Help!" "Hey!"
as blades skip and crash, the bubble of the overturned copter, Pilot trapped inside, sinks into the sea.
Pilot struggling with his safety harness, trying to hit switches, working on instinct. Some air in the bubble, but water too, and sparks as electrical connections short out and burn.
A parallel struggle for survival, as the current separates Sean from the other Kids; Marge is gone, the little boy is clinging alone to the free-floating Lightening.
The raft shudders, and begins to break up under the pounding.
Huddled in the cracked plastic bubble, the Pilot is sucking air from his oxygen tank. He sees Marge, and slips out of his bubble, headed for her.
Scuttling like two crabs into the shelter of the broken chopper, buddy breathing as he passes her the oxygen tube.
Success. He's pulled to safety. They lash his little hull as tight as they can to the rest of the floating wreckage.
held by only a few screws, it pulls out of its mount and shatters on the deck.
picks himself up, and staggers to the rail, sees his predicament.
the Kids find some line. Andy coils, and throws.

Brady catches the Kids' line. He heaves on it with all his might. Nothing. Jackie is hysterical, some of the other Kids are screaming. The Shark's fin catches the taut line, it slides up and over, Brody and the Kids are nearly pulled into the water. The raft doesn't budge.
the Kids react to this fresh attack.
The winch smokes and stalls, the weight it's pulling almost too much.
While Brody inflates the rubber raft and throws it in the water, the Kids scramble for safety, swimming for their lives. Each one is sure this moment is going to be his last.
grinding, smoking, hauling something out of the water -- heavy, slimy, dripping metal cable, the main powerline from the mainland!
paddling the raft towards Sean with desperate strokes, heedless of the danger around him.

He hears the horrendous sounds of wood and metal breaking, as the raft pounds to pieces on the rocks. He is blinded by the sweeping searchlight, the confusion of terror-stricken teen-agers screaming. It's the middle of The Inferno.

Silhouetted against the evening sky. Automatic timers are turning on navigation and worklights, illuminating the barren rocks and rusty steel with their glare -- throwing dark shadows, putting the surrounding water into black limbo by their contract.
with the Kids clinging like drowned rats to the rocks; they're wet, scared, exhausted, but safe. Sean hugs his daddy as they step onto land.
